data.text:
Dressed in grey, Christine of Sweden appears on a rearing horse, which symbolizes her status as queen and her power in seventeenth-century Europe. The presence of a falconer beside the dogs alludes to her high station, as hunting was an exercised reserved for royalty and aristocracy. Bourdon made various official images of the Swedish queen, but this one stands out because it is an outdoor and equestrian portrait. This portrait was intended for the Spanish king, Felipe IV, as a reminder of the Swedish queen´s reaffirmation on the Catholic side of the Thirty Years´ War. In 1666 it was already hanging in a preeminent location at Madrid´s Alcázar Palace, where it served as an official portrait.
